name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
theory:
Boundaries (MALT Mnemonic)

  • Muscle (Roof): Internal Oblique & Transversus Abdominis fibers (Conjoint tendon).
  • Aponeurosis (Anterior): External Oblique Aponeurosis.
  • Ligament (Floor): Inguinal Ligament (Poupart's) & Lacunar Ligament medially.
  • Transversalis (Posterior): Transversalis Fascia.

Contents

  • Males: Spermatic Cord + Ilioinguinal Nerve.
  • Females: Round Ligament of Uterus + Ilioinguinal Nerve.
clinical:
Hernias

The canal is a potential site of weakness.
Deep Ring: Located at the mid-inguinal point (halfway between ASIS and Pubic Symphysis). Site of Indirect Hernias.
Superficial Ring: Defect in external oblique aponeurosis above pubic tubercle.
Nerve Entrapment: The Ilioinguinal nerve runs on top of the cord (not inside) and can be damaged during hernia repair, causing numbness in the inner thigh/scrotum.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž MALT Mnemonic
Muscle (Roof), Anterior (Aponeurosis), Ligament (Floor), Transversalis (Posterior).
ðŸ’Ž Mid-Inguinal Point vs Midpoint of Inguinal Ligament
Mid-Inguinal Point: Halfway between ASIS and Symphysis. Landmark for Femoral Pulse and Deep Ring.
Midpoint of Inguinal Ligament: Halfway between ASIS and Tubercle. Landmark for nerve blocks.

name: Calot's Triangle (Biliary)
theory:
Boundaries

  • Superior: Inferior border of the Liver.
  • Medial: Common Hepatic Duct.
  • Lateral: Cystic Duct.

Contents

  • Cystic Artery: Usually arises from the Right Hepatic Artery.
  • Lund's Node: The sentinel lymph node of the gallbladder.
clinical:
Cholecystectomy

This is the critical view of safety during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The Cystic Duct and Cystic Artery must be identified within this triangle and clipped/cut. Failure to identify anomalies here can lead to Common Bile Duct injury or Right Hepatic Artery bleeding.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Moynihan's Hump
A torture or loop of the Right Hepatic Artery that projects into Calot's triangle. It can be easily mistaken for the cystic artery and ligated, causing liver necrosis.

name: Blood Supply of the Gut
theory:
The Three Trunks

  • Celiac Trunk (Foregut): Stomach, Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, Duodenum (proximal). Branches: Left Gastric, Splenic, Common Hepatic.
  • SMA (Midgut): Distal Duodenum to distal transverse colon. Branches: Ileocolic, Right Colic, Middle Colic.
  • IMA (Hindgut): Distal transverse colon to rectum. Branches: Left Colic, Sigmoid, Superior Rectal.
clinical:
Ischemic Colitis

Occurs at 'Watershed Areas' where blood supply from two major arteries overlaps (weakest perfusion).
Griffiths' Point: Splenic flexure (Junction of SMA/IMA).
Sudeck's Point: Rectosigmoid junction (Junction of IMA/Internal Iliac).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Marginal Artery of Drummond
A continuous arterial arcade along the inner border of the colon connecting the SMA and IMA systems. Crucial for collateral flow.

name: Femoral Triangle
theory:
Boundaries (SAIL)

  • Sartorius (Lateral).
  • Adductor Longus (Medial).
  • Inguinal Ligament (Superior).
  • Floor: Pectineus, Iliopsoas, Adductor Longus.
  • Roof: Fascia Lata.

Contents (Lateral to Medial: NAVEL)

  • Nerve (Femoral) - Outside the sheath!
  • Artery (Femoral).
  • Vein (Femoral).
  • Empty Space (Femoral Canal - Hernia site).
  • Lymphatics (Cloquet's Node).
clinical:
Femoral Hernia

Occurs through the Femoral Canal (Empty space).
Neck Boundaries:
- Anterior: Inguinal Ligament.
- Posterior: Pectineal Ligament.
- Lateral: Femoral Vein.
- Medial: Lacunar Ligament (sharp/rigid -> causes strangulation).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Femoral Sheath
Contains the Artery, Vein, and Canal. The Femoral Nerve is NOT in the sheath (important for nerve blocks - must inject outside the vessels).

name: Surgical Incisions
theory:
Common Types

  • Midline: Through the Linea Alba (avascular). Rapid access, good exposure. High hernia risk.
  • Kocher's: Right subcostal (Open Cholecystectomy).
  • Lanz: Transverse RIF incision (Appendectomy). Cosmetic result better than Gridiron.
  • Pfannenstiel: Transverse suprapubic (C-Section/Pelvic surgery). Very strong repair.
  • Mercedes Benz: Rooftop incision with vertical extension (Liver transplant).
clinical:
Complications

Incisional Hernia: Most common in midline incisions due to tension.
Nerve Injury: Iliohypogastric nerve damage in RIF incisions (appendectomy) causes sensation loss over the suprapubic area.
Dehiscence: Burst abdomen. Surgical emergency.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Langer's Lines
Natural skin tension lines. Incisions made parallel to these lines heal with minimal scarring (e.g., collar incision for thyroid). Incisions perpendicular result in wide, hypertrophic scars.

name: Sutures & Materials
theory:
Classification

  • Absorbable: Broken down by hydrolysis or enzymatic reaction.
    - Vicryl (Polyglactin): Braided. Holds tension 2-3 weeks. Bowel/Subcut.
    - Monocryl (Poliglecaprone): Monofilament. Skin closure.
    - PDS (Polydioxanone): Monofilament. Long lasting (6 weeks). Fascia closure.
  • Non-Absorbable: Permanent.
    - Prolene (Polypropylene): Vascular/Hernia mesh. Inert.
    - Silk: Braided. Drains/Ligation.
    - Ethilon (Nylon): Skin sutures (needs removal).
clinical:
Selection Guide

  • Bowel Anastomosis: PDS or Vicryl (absorbable).
  • Vascular Anastomosis: Prolene (non-absorbable, smooth flow).
  • Skin (Face): Ethilon 6-0 (remove day 5).
  • Abdominal Fascia (Mass closure): PDS loop (strong, long lasting).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Suture Sizes
The higher the number, the thinner the suture.
1 = Thick (Abdominal wall).
2-0 = Medium (Bowel).
10-0 = Microscopic (Eye/Nerve).

name: Post-Op Fever (5 W's)
theory:
The 5 W's Mnemonic

  • Day 1-2: Wind (Lungs): Atelectasis (collapse of alveoli) or Pneumonia.
  • Day 3-5: Water (Urine): Urinary Tract Infection (Catheter associated).
  • Day 5-7: Wound (Site): Surgical Site Infection (SSI) or Abscess.
  • Day 7+: Walk (DVT): Deep Vein Thrombosis / PE.
  • Anytime: Wonder Drugs (or What did we do): Drug fever, Blood transfusion reaction, Cannula site phlebitis.
clinical:
Workup (Septic Screen)

  • Exam: Listen to chest, inspect wound, check calves, check cannula sites.
  • Labs: FBC, CRP, Blood Cultures, Urine Culture.
  • Imaging: CXR (Atelectasis), Doppler (DVT), CT (Abscess/Leak).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Atelectasis
The most common cause of fever in the first 48 hours. Caused by shallow breathing (pain/anesthesia). Treatment: Chest physiotherapy and incentive spirometry (not antibiotics).

name: Fluid Management
theory:
Daily Requirements (Adult)

  • Water: 25-30 ml/kg/day.
  • Sodium (Na+): 1 mmol/kg/day.
  • Potassium (K+): 1 mmol/kg/day.
  • Glucose: 50-100g to prevent ketosis.
clinical:
Types of Fluid

  • Crystalloids:
    - Hartmann's (Lactated Ringer's): Balanced salt solution. physiological. Best for resuscitation/intra-op.
    - 0.9% Saline: High chloride. Large volumes cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
    - 5% Dextrose: Distributed to all compartments. Good for maintenance water, useless for resuscitation (stays in vessels for minutes).
  • Colloids: Gelofusine/Albumin. Rarely used now for resuscitation.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Potassium Rules
Never give Potassium as a stat bolus (Cardiac arrest). Maximum peripheral rate is 10mmol/hour. Always check renal function first (Don't put K+ in if no pee coming out).

name: ASA Grading
theory:
American Society of Anesthesiologists

Used to assess fitness for surgery.
  • ASA I: Normal healthy patient.
  • ASA II: Mild systemic disease (Controlled HTN, Smoker, Pregnancy).
  • ASA III: Severe systemic disease (Stable Angina, COPD, poorly controlled DM).
  • ASA IV: Severe disease threatening life (Unstable Angina, Sepsis, Renal Failure).
  • ASA V: Moribund (Ruptured AAA).
  • ASA E: Emergency suffix (e.g., ASA IIIE).
clinical:
Relevance

ASA grade correlates directly with peri-operative mortality. ASA III and above usually require High Dependency Unit (HDU) or ICU post-op care.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž NPO Guidelines (Fasting)
2-4-6 Rule:
2 Hours: Clear fluids (Water).
4 Hours: Breast milk.
6 Hours: Solids/Light meal.
